title: ExpulsiÃ³n de Mayra RamÃ­rez en Francia vs. Colombia en Juegos OlÃ­mpicos: foto
text: En juego por la primera fecha de la fase de grupos de los Juegos OlÃ­mpicos, la SelecciÃ³n Colombia femenina tuvo un debut complicado frente a la anfitriona: Francia. AllÃ­, una jugada en especÃ­fico se llevÃ³ la mirada de todos, pues Mayra RamÃ­rez le hizo una fuerte entrada a Selma Bacha.(Vea tambiÃ©n: QuÃ© partidos se pierde Mayra RamÃ­rez en los Juegos OlÃ­mpicos; el debut le saliÃ³ caro)Cerca del minuto 82, en una fuerte disputa por el balÃ³n, la colombiana terminÃ³ por entrarle al tobillo a la francesa, quien se quejÃ³ de gran manera debido a la vehemencia de la entrada, ademÃ¡s de la zona a la que terminÃ³ golpeando.En principio, la juez central, Tori Penso, le mostrÃ³ la tarjeta amarilla a la jugadora, pero tras un llamado del VAR y una larga revisiÃ³n de la acciÃ³n, se decidiÃ³ anular aquella tarjeta, para terminar mostrÃ¡ndole la roja directa. La â€˜9â€™ saliÃ³ notablemente molesta por la decisiÃ³n, yÃ©ndose a las duchas de manera tempranera a falta de pocos minutos de finalizar el partido.Â¿Mayra RamÃ­rez merecÃ­a expulsiÃ³n en Juegos OlÃ­mpicos?Respecto a esta jugada, AndrÃ©s Grimaldo, analista arbitral, quien es el responsable de la cuenta El VAR Central, dedicada a examinar minuciosamente cualquier jugada que cause un poco de polÃ©mica, dio su punto de vista respecto a la jugada entre RamÃ­rez y Bacha.ğŸŸ¥ ES ROJA: Entrada de Mayra RamÃ­rez en la zona del tendÃ³n de aquiles. Le alcanza a arrastrar el pie a la francesa en una imagen que se vio bastante fea. Juego brusco y grave que se resuelve con ayuda del VAR para Tori Penso #Paris2024 pic.twitter.com/P8GNH6Ephgâ€” El VAR Central (AndrÃ©s) (@ElVarCentral) July 25, 2024Pues bien, para el VAR Central la entrada de Mayra estuvo bien sancionada con la roja, ya que la zona en la que fue el contacto es frÃ¡gil, pudiendo tambiÃ©n incidir en la salud de la francesa.â€œES ROJA: Entrada de Mayra RamÃ­rez en la zona del tendÃ³n de aquiles. Le alcanza a arrastrar el pie a la francesa en una imagen que se vio bastante fea. Juego brusco y grave que se resuelve con ayuda del VAR para Tori Pensoâ€, fue lo que expresÃ³ AndrÃ©s Grimaldo, respecto a la jugada que terminÃ³ dejando a la SelecciÃ³n Colombia con una jugadora menos. Lee TambiÃ©n QuÃ© partidos se pierde Mayra RamÃ­rez en los Juegos OlÃ­mpicos; el debut le saliÃ³ caro Por quÃ© camiseta de SelecciÃ³n Colombia Femenina no tuvo el escudo tradicional en JJ. OO. author: @KGNSnews
title: LISD student makes breakthrough in cancer research
text:
LISD student makes breakthrough in cancer research
LAREDO, Tex. (KGNS) - A student from Laredo is achieving a medical breakthrough that could aid in the fight against cancer.
Texas A&M International University student and Garcia Early College Senior Pablo Guzman is making his mark in biomedical research.
At just 17 years old, Guzman and his team are developing a potential treatment for a specific type of cancer, which has already been recognized by the American Chemical Society.
After losing three family members to cancer, Guzman dedicated himself to learning more about the disease in hopes of one day helping others diagnosed with it.
With extensive research and lab work, Guzman and his team developed a treatment similar to a nicotine patch that may be effective in treating skin cancer.
â€œI thought, â€˜Well, something that we could do is have it deliver some sort of chemotherapy instead.â€™ Currently, chemotherapy has a big drawback in that it requires a big dosage, and that has a few problems. The tumor can build resistance to chemo, so you need higher dosages. My thought process was, â€˜Letâ€™s reduce the dosage needed,â€™ and weâ€™ve been at the lab trying to solve that. Weâ€™ve had excellent results,â€œ Guzman said.
Guzman is scheduled to graduate this year and plans to attend Texas A&M University in College Station. He intends to stay in touch with his research team and continue building on the work they have already started.
He is scheduled to hold a conference on April 11, during which he will present his findings to students and fellow researchers.
In a separate article, we learn more from Guzman about his research and his academic journey.
For more headlines, click here.

author: admin
title: Pushi Chinese Culture Studio Volunteers Capture Moments at 2nd Chinese Drama Competition
text:
â€œChinese Drama Competition Celebrates Culture Through Culinary Themesâ€
The 2nd Chinese Drama Competition, sponsored by Nuxi Chinese Culture Studio (NECCS), took place on March 9 at the Boston Overseas Chinese Education Center. Hosted as part of a series of traditional Chinese character activities, the event saw participants showcasing their talents in the world of drama and performance.
With the theme of â€œFood Tasteâ€ for the senior group, siblings Lin Yuelun and Lin Zhuowei from Lexington Chinese School captivated the audience with their culinary-inspired performance. The middle grade group, themed â€œMom and Dad Love to Cook,â€ featured students from Boston Tzu Chi Humanities School and China Guangjiao School bringing their own twists to the stage.
Volunteers from Pushi Chinese Culture Studio added a unique touch to the competition by taking photos with contestants holding kitchen props. Pushi President Feng Wenluan praised the integration of spoken Chinese and cultural experience into the performances, highlighting the practical learning opportunities provided by the event.
The competition also featured insightful feedback from Judge Professor Gao Xinyi, who encouraged participants to engage with the audience both on and off stage. As the contestants navigated the challenges of dramatic performance, they received valuable advice on maintaining clarity and composure during their acts.
Following the competition, a relaxed discussion allowed students and parents to share their experiences and offer suggestions for future events. Parents noted the valuable connections forged during the preparation process, emphasizing the positive impact on family dynamics and cultural exchanges.
In an effort to enhance performance skills, Pushi culture teachers Li Yuying and Lu Yongyi demonstrated collaborative techniques and encouraged experiential learning. By engaging in activities related to the performance theme, such as cooking with parents, students were able to refine their skills and deepen their understanding of traditional Chinese culture.
As the curtain closed on the 2nd Chinese Drama Competition, participants left with a renewed appreciation for the intersection of language, culture, and performance art. With plans for future competitions and continued cultural exchange, the event served as a testament to the vibrant tradition of Chinese drama in the community.
Editor in charge: Feng Wenluan

author: La redazione
title: De Zerbi show: poker al Tottenham di Postecoglou!
text:
La 19Âª regala un'altra grandissima sorpresa, con il Brighton di De Zerbi che si impone con un poker sul Tottenham . Risultato durissimo, con un 4-2 che permette alla squadra del tecnico italiano di ripartire dopo tre turni senza vittorie, e che frena gli Spurs dopo tre vittorie di fila. Nell'altra partita della giornata si sfidano Arsenal e West Ham .
De Zerbi show, poker al Tottenham! Il Tottenham, chiamato a rispondere alle squadre in testa alla classifica per restare in coda, crolla a sorpresa contro De Zerbi . Parte malissimo la partita della squadra di Postecoglou , con Hinshelwood e Joao Pedro (su rigore) che portano avanti il Brighton nei primi venti minuti. Nella ripresa non arriva la reazione degli Spurs, e anzi i padroni di casa dilagano con Estupian e ancora Joao Pedro su rigore per completare il poker . Il Tottenham si sveglia solo all'80', provando a reagire con Veliz e Davies , ma non Ã¨ abbastanza. Frenata di Postecoglou, che resta quinto con 37 punti. Scatto in avanti di De Zerbi , ora ottavo con 30 punti.

But while many blame the charging device, in many cases it is because the vehicle's tech is incapable of reaching the peak...

author: Irishexaminer.com (digitaldesk@irishexaminer.com)
title: Green Earth Organics: Going back to our vegetable roots
text:
"If you buy Irish, then that encourages the Irish vegetable industry to expand.â€
Itâ€™s all very simple when organic farmer Kenneth Keavey, who runs vegetable box delivery business Green Earth Organics, explains it like that. But the stark fact remains: despite our climate being ideal for growing â€” at least most of the time â€” only 1% of Irish farms produce vegetables, according to 2016 Eurostat figures.
The percentage of Irish farms growing organic vegetables is even lower but Keavey has been bucking trends since he returned from Britain in 2004 with his wife Jenny to take over the family farm in County Galway.
Growing up in Ireland during the 1980s recession, it wasnâ€™t a given that Keavey would go into farming: his father always made sure he had options: â€œDad always wanted me to be experienced on the farming side and get used to hard work but he also knew it was important to get an education.â€
Keavey did applied chemistry at UCG and then continued his studies with a PhD in medical chemistry at the University of Cambridge. â€œI decided, with all the experience I had in farming, that I didnâ€™t want to go down that road. Instead,â€ he laughs, â€œI went into the dark side of the industry, working as an organic chemist.â€
SUSTAINABILITY & CLIMATE
Check out our
Sustainability and Climate Change Hub where you will find the latest news, features, opinions and analysis on this topic from across the various Irish Examiner topic desks and their team of specialist writers and columnists.
But the land called him home. â€œThe family farm was here, Dad was talking about selling it, and I wanted a change,â€ says Keavey. â€œI wasn't happy doing the kind of work I was doing. My wife and I quit our jobs and moved back in 2004.â€
It wasnâ€™t an easy start, making the leap from a farm with â€œsheep and cows and hayâ€ into vegetable growing.
Putting up a polytunnel on the land, at a time before everyone had polytunnels in their back garden, caused some consternation: â€œThe local gardai turned up. They were very suspicious of what we were growing.â€
The couple wasn't dissuaded though. â€œWe went off down our mad path, growing veg and really enjoyed it. We were growing food that respected where we were from.â€
Starting a vegetable box delivery scheme in 2006 was a game changer. â€œThe first 30 went out to friends and family, and from then, it, ahem, grew organically.â€
Their veg box offering includes produce from their farm and other local organic growers alongside imported organic fruit and vegetables, ensuring thereâ€™s always a selection available. Making it convenient to access quality vegetables and fruit enabled the company to weather the financial ups and downs of the late noughties and the years impacted by covid shutdowns.
On its website, Green Earth Organics also sells a comprehensive selection of organic pantry items (nuts, beans, flours) and eco-friendly cleaning products alongside fresh organic Irish foods like Butlersâ€™ eggs, Blakeâ€™s kefir and Mossfield cheese, yoghurt and milk. Its 100% Irish farm box, which includes organic beetroot, kale, cabbage and mushrooms, along with Achill sea salt, bulk bags of unwaxed oranges, pasta, Dunany flour, organic tinned tomatoes, and Lilly's Eco Clean washing-up liquid makes Green Earth Organics a one-stop shop for anyone who wants to source organic products.
The nationwide delivery fee is â‚¬5.50, and there is no charge for orders over â‚¬100.
Order deadlines and delivery days depend on where you are in the country. In Cork, I can order by 10am Wednesday for delivery on Friday, making sure I have fresh (and occasionally muddy) Irish-grown vegetables for weekend cooking.
Selling direct through online vegetable box orders and in the farm shop they run on Saturdays at their base in Caherlea (just over 15 km from Galway city) is how Green Earth Organics manages to make everything work.
â€œWe developed our own retail business to circumnavigate the supermarkets,â€ says Keavey who used to sell into the multiples until he realised it didnâ€™t make financial sense for his business.
Growing is not an easy job â€” â€œ itâ€™s bloody hard workâ€ â€” and Keavey finds it frustrating that supermarkets use fresh food as loss leaders, devaluing the price of Irish-grown vegetables. Heâ€™s very good at communicating about the imbalance on social media, talking to camera about the vagaries of vegetable growing in Ireland while walking the fields.
â€œFood grown closer to where itâ€™s consumed makes more sense,â€ Keavey points out. â€œThere are less carbon emissions, itâ€™s fresher â€” as itâ€™s travelled less of a distance â€” and therefore has more nutrients. You have more confidence in food that's grown locally, and thereâ€™s more food security. Itâ€™s good for us and itâ€™s better for the environment.â€
While the 100% Irish farm box (â‚¬30) is the most popular offering on the Green Earth Organics website, Keavey knows itâ€™s a big ask to have people eating only Irish-grown vegetables at this time of the year. â€œThereâ€™s the idea of eating sustainably and locally and then thereâ€™s the reality. Sometimes that doesnâ€™t align. In July, itâ€™s great â€” we have tomatoes, beans, cucumber available â€” but at the moment, itâ€™s all roots and traditional Irish veg and eating seasonally becomes more difficult.â€
By offering a mixture of Irish-grown and imported organic fruit and vegetables Keavey can keep Green Earth Organics customers supplied throughout the year. â€œYou have to be realistic about it. There are things you just canâ€™t grow successfully in Ireland.â€
I, for one, wouldnâ€™t wish to be without access to imported lemons - good for brightening up the flavour of that Irish savoy cabbage â€” or bitter oranges for marmalade making.
By buying Irish when possible and increasing demand, consumers can make a real difference. â€œSupport for the industry leads to more Irish-grown vegetables on the shelves,â€ says Keavey, â€œand thatâ€™s better for everybody.â€
greenearthorganics.ie
